quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's inspired by people. It's created by people, and most importantly, it impacts people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A human-centered framing practitioners can use to guide product, policy, and deployment decisions in AI.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In fact, I believe that whatever AI does, currently or in the future, is up to us. It's up to the people.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A responsibility model that shifts AI outcomes from inevitability to human choice and governance.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I do believe technology is a net positive for humanity, but I think every technology is a double-edged sword. If we're not doing the right thing as a society, as individuals, we can screw this up as well.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A practical risk lens for teams to pair optimism with safeguards, incentives, and accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In the middle of 2015, middle of 2016, some tech companies avoid using the word AI because they were not sure if AI was a dirty word. 2017-ish was the beginning of companies calling themselves AI companies.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder of how quickly narratives shift—useful for timing bets and branding around emerging tech.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In order to train computers with tens and thousands of object concepts, you really need to show it millions of examples.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete scaling heuristic for practitioners: capability often follows data volume and coverage, not just algorithms.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Suddenly, I can involve my whole team in the design process, give feedback on design concepts really quickly and it just made the whole product development process so much more fun.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a practical collaboration model: broaden participation and tighten feedback loops to improve product development.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With just a few prompts, you can make any idea or design into a fully functional prototype or app that anyone can iterate on and validate with customers.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable methodology for rapid prototyping: prompt-to-prototype, then iterate and validate with customers quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Stop spending so much time telling people about your product vision and instead show it to them.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A memorable product communication principle: use tangible demos/prototypes to align stakeholders faster than explanations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: My team is spread out across Colorado, Australia, Nepal, West Africa, and San Francisco.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete example of a globally distributed team setup that underscores the operational realities of modern hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Justworks knows that your employees are more than just your employees; they're your people.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A people-first framing that can guide HR and management decisions beyond purely transactional employment thinking.

quotes.topic_title: AI optimism, humanism, and societal responsibility
quotes.text: I'm not a utopian, so it's not like I think AI will have no impact on jobs or people. In fact, I'm a humanist. I believe that whatever AI does, currently or in the future, is up to us. It's up to the people.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A clear mental model for “non-utopian optimism” that places agency and responsibility on human choices rather than inevitability.

quotes.topic_title: AI optimism, humanism, and societal responsibility
quotes.text: But I think every technology is a double-edged sword, and if we're not doing the right thing as a species, as a society, as communities, as individuals, we can screw this up as well.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A practical risk lens: treat AI like prior technologies—benefits aren’t automatic and require deliberate governance at multiple levels.

quotes.topic_title: AI optimism, humanism, and societal responsibility
quotes.text: There's nothing artificial about AI. It's inspired by people. It's created by people, and most importantly, it impacts people.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that pushes practitioners to evaluate AI systems by human origins and human consequences, not just technical performance.

quotes.topic_title: AI optimism, humanism, and societal responsibility
quotes.text: No matter which part of the AI development or AI deployment or AI application you are participating in, and most likely many of us, especially as technologists, we're in multiple points. We should act like responsible individuals and care about this. Actually, care a lot about this.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for builders and deployers: responsibility applies across the entire lifecycle, not just to “ethics teams” or policymakers.

quotes.topic_title: AI optimism, humanism, and societal responsibility
quotes.text: I think everybody today should care about AI because it is going to impact your individual life. It is going to impact your community, it's going to impact the society and the future generation.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A scope-and-stakes framing that helps prioritize AI work by its ripple effects from individuals to future generations.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from Turing to machine learning
quotes.text: That stretch about 20 years is actually the beginning of machine learning, is the marriage between computer programming and statistical learning.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Defines a clear mental model for what changed in AI’s evolution: combining programming with statistics to enable learning from data.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from Turing to machine learning
quotes.text: And that marriage brought a very, very critical concept into AI, which is that purely rule-based program is not going to account for the vast amount of cognitive capabilities that we imagine computers can do.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A contrarian correction to rule-based thinking that practitioners can use to guide when to prefer learning systems over hand-coded logic.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from Turing to machine learning
quotes.text: So we have to use machines to learn the patterns.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A succinct, actionable principle for building AI systems: prioritize pattern learning rather than enumerating rules.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from Turing to machine learning
quotes.text: For example, if you give it three cats, the hope is not just for the machines to recognize these three cats. The hope is the machines can recognize the fourth cat, the fifth cat, the sixth cat, and all the other cats.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete example of generalization—the core capability practitioners should measure when evaluating ML models.

quotes.topic_title: AI’s evolution: from Turing to machine learning
quotes.text: I chose to look at artificial intelligence through the lens of visual intelligence because humans are deeply visual animals.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A strategic research/product framing: grounding AI in perception and vision as a foundation for broader intelligence.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: my students and I are very committed to a north star problem, which is solving the problem of object recognition because it's a building block for the perceptual world, right?
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A practical research methodology: pick a single “north star” problem that serves as a foundational building block for broader capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: And there was one singular pain point is that these models don't have data to be trained on.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A diagnostic lens for practitioners: when progress stalls, the bottleneck may be data availability rather than model sophistication.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: it dawned on me that human learning as well as evolution is actually a big data learning process.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A mental model that reframes AI progress around scaling experience/data, not just inventing new algorithms.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: I think my students and I conjectured that a very critically-overlooked ingredient of bringing AI to life is big data.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterintuitive emphasis (especially for model-centric teams): the “missing ingredient” may be dataset scale/coverage.

quotes.topic_title: ImageNet: big data as the missing ingredient
quotes.text: We curated very carefully, 15 million images on the internet, created a taxonomy of 22,000 concepts, borrowing other researchers' work like linguists work on WordNet, and it's a particular way of dictionarying words.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete, replicable approach to building high-leverage datasets: careful curation + explicit taxonomy + reuse of existing ontologies.

quotes.topic_title: 2012 deep learning inflection and core recipe
quotes.text: We curated very carefully, 15 million images on the internet, created a taxonomy of 22,000 concepts, borrowing other researchers' work like linguists work on WordNet, and it's a particular way of dictionarying words.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for scaling ML progress: pair massive data curation with a well-structured taxonomy built on prior community knowledge.

quotes.topic_title: 2012 deep learning inflection and core recipe
quotes.text: 2012 was the moment that many people think was the beginning of the deep learning or birth of modern AI because a group of Toronto researchers led by Professor Geoff Hinton, participated in ImageNet Challenge, used ImageNet big data and two GPUs from NVIDIA
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A specific historical data point showing how a small amount of commodity compute plus the right dataset catalyzed a major inflection point.

quotes.topic_title: 2012 deep learning inflection and core recipe
quotes.text: And that combination of the trio technology, big data, neural network, and GPU was kind of the golden recipe for modern AI.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A memorable mental model practitioners can use to diagnose and design AI breakthroughs: data + architecture + compute.

quotes.topic_title: 2012 deep learning inflection and core recipe
quotes.text: if you look at the ingredients of what brought ChatGPT to the world technically still use these three ingredients.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterweight to novelty hype: today’s LLMs still follow the same core recipe as early deep learning successes.

quotes.topic_title: 2012 deep learning inflection and core recipe
quotes.text: I was actually encouraging everybody to use the word AI because to me that is one of the most audacious question humanity has ever asked in our quest for science and technology, and I feel very proud of this term.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A reframing that can guide practitioners’ communication and ambition: treat “AI” as a legitimate, motivating scientific north star rather than a taboo buzzword.

quotes.topic_title: When “AI” was a dirty word in industry
quotes.text: some tech companies avoid using the word AI because they were not sure if AI was a dirty word.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete example of how branding and perceived risk can suppress adoption of a technology term even inside leading tech companies.

quotes.topic_title: When “AI” was a dirty word in industry
quotes.text: I remember I was actually encouraging everybody to use the word AI because to me that is one of the most audacious question humanity has ever asked in our quest for science and technology, and I feel very proud of this term.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Actionable positioning advice: confidently name and frame the work as “AI” to align teams and stakeholders around an ambitious mission.

quotes.topic_title: When “AI” was a dirty word in industry
quotes.text: 2016, I think because that was-
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A specific time marker showing how recently “AI” carried stigma in industry conversations.

quotes.topic_title: When “AI” was a dirty word in industry
quotes.text: I think 2017-ish was the beginning of companies calling themselves AI companies.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A useful historical inflection point for practitioners tracking how market narratives and company identity shifted around AI.

quotes.topic_title: When “AI” was a dirty word in industry
quotes.text: AI is a field of, at this point, 70 years old and we have gone through many generations. Nobody, no one could have gotten here by themselves.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterweight to founder-hero narratives: progress comes from long, multi-generation research ecosystems rather than lone geniuses.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: I feel AGI is more a marketing term than a scientific term as a scientist than technologist.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A contrarian framing that encourages practitioners to treat “AGI” claims skeptically and focus on measurable scientific progress.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: Oh no, I definitely think we need more innovations.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Direct guidance that scaling alone isn’t sufficient—teams should plan for new ideas beyond more data/compute.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: Today, you take a model and run it through a video of a couple of office rooms and ask the model to count the number of chairs. And this is something a toddler could do or maybe an elementary school kid could do, and AI could not do that, right?
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete evaluation example practitioners can use to reveal gaps in perception and grounded reasoning despite impressive demos.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: We have no way of enabling AI to do that today.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A blunt reality check about current limits in creativity/abstraction, useful for setting product and research expectations.

quotes.topic_title: AGI skepticism and limits of current systems
quotes.text: Let's give AI all the data including modern instruments data of celestial bodies, which Newton did not have, and give it to that and just ask AI to create the 17th century set of equations on the laws of bodily movements. Today's AI cannot do that.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A memorable benchmark-style thought experiment for testing whether systems can derive fundamental abstractions from rich data.

quotes.topic_title: World models and spatial intelligence: what and why
quotes.text: I come from the world of visual intelligence and I was just thinking there's so much we can push forward beyond language because humans, humans use our sense of spatial intelligence, a world understanding to do so many things and they are beyond language.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A clear mental model for practitioners: many high-impact AI capabilities require spatial/world understanding, not just language.

quotes.topic_title: World models and spatial intelligence: what and why
quotes.text: Language is part of that, but a lot of those situations, language cannot get you to put down the fire.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that real-world competence (e.g., emergency response) demands embodied/spatial intelligence beyond LLMs.

quotes.topic_title: World models and spatial intelligence: what and why
quotes.text: I was doing a lot of robotics research and it dawned on me that the linchpin of connecting the additional intelligence, in addition to language embodied AI, which are robotics, connecting visual intelligence, is the sense of spatial intelligence about understanding the world.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A practical systems view: spatial intelligence is the connecting layer between vision and robotics for embodied AI.

quotes.topic_title: World models and spatial intelligence: what and why
quotes.text: So world model is a foundation that you can use to reason, to interact, and to create worlds.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concise definition practitioners can use to scope product requirements: creation + interaction + reasoning as core capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: World models and spatial intelligence: what and why
quotes.text: But with that 2D flat photo, the humans, especially two important humans, James Watson and Francis Crick, in addition to their other information, was able to reason in 3D space and deduce a highly three-dimensional double helix structure of the DNA.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete example showing why spatial reasoning matters for scientific discovery and how AI-assisted spatial intelligence could amplify it.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whether you're sending marketing campaigns, verification codes, or account alerts, you need them to reach users reliably.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: Highlights reliability as the core requirement across multiple customer-communication use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 150,000 businesses, including 8 of the top 10 largest tech companies globally use Sinch's API to build messaging, email, and calling into their products.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point and a specific example of how product teams integrate communications via APIs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Think of RCS as SMS2.0.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: Offers a simple mental model for positioning RCS as the next iteration of SMS for product and messaging strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Instead of getting texts from a random number, your users will see your verified company name and logo without needing to download anything new.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: Actionable product insight: branded, verified sender identity can improve trust and recognition without adding user friction.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And here's why this matters, US carriers are starting to adopt RCS.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Sinch ad read)
quotes.context: Signals a market timing inflection point practitioners can use to prioritize RCS readiness.

quotes.topic_title: The bitter lesson and why robotics is harder
quotes.text: it turns out simpler model with a ton of data always win at the end of the day instead of the more complex model with less data.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A crisp statement of Sutton’s “bitter lesson” that can guide practitioners toward prioritizing scale and data over hand-crafted complexity.

quotes.topic_title: The bitter lesson and why robotics is harder
quotes.text: I'm very jealous of my colleagues in language because they had this perfect setup where their training data are in words, eventually tokens, and then they produce a model that outputs words.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Highlights an alignment advantage in language modeling that robotics lacks, framing why simply scaling data is harder in embodied domains.

quotes.topic_title: The bitter lesson and why robotics is harder
quotes.text: You hope to get actions out of robots, but your training data lacks actions in 3D worlds, and that's what robots have to do, right? Actions in 3D worlds.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Defines the core data/target mismatch in robotics—an actionable problem statement for dataset, simulation, and teleop collection strategies.

quotes.topic_title: The bitter lesson and why robotics is harder
quotes.text: So then we have to start talking about adding supplementing data such as teleoperation data or synthetic data so that the robots are trained with this hypothesis of bitter lesson, which is large amount of data.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Concrete advice on how robotics teams can close the action-data gap by augmenting web video with teleop and synthetic data.

quotes.topic_title: The bitter lesson and why robotics is harder
quotes.text: It's 20 years since that prototype of a self-driving car being able to drive 130 miles in the Nevada desert to today's Waymo and on the street of San Francisco.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A sobering timeline data point that sets expectations for long, multi-decade productization cycles in physical autonomy.

quotes.topic_title: Awe at human intelligence and energy efficiency
quotes.text: Totally. We operate on about 20 watts. That's dimmer than any light bulb in the room I'm in right now.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete energy-efficiency data point that reframes human intelligence as an engineering benchmark for AI systems.

quotes.topic_title: Awe at human intelligence and energy efficiency
quotes.text: And yet we can do so much. So I think actually the more I work in AI, the more I respect humans.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterintuitive takeaway that building AI can increase appreciation for human capabilities, guiding practitioners to use humans as a north-star reference point.

quotes.topic_title: Awe at human intelligence and energy efficiency
quotes.text: Just the complexity just to get a machine to just walk around and not hit things and fall, does just give you more respect for what we've already got?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights how seemingly simple embodied tasks expose hidden complexity, a useful mental model for scoping robotics and autonomy work.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: first large world model product
quotes.text: we believe that spatial intelligence and world modeling is as important, if not more, to language models and complementary to language models.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A clear strategic framework for practitioners: treat world models as a complementary (and potentially more important) pillar alongside LLMs.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: first large world model product
quotes.text: we wanted to seize this opportunity to create deep tech research lab that can connect the dots between frontier models with products.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A product-development methodology: explicitly build an org/process that bridges frontier research to shippable products.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: first large world model product
quotes.text: We've spent a year and plus building the world's first generative model that can output genuinely 3D worlds. That's a very, very hard problem.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A concrete data point on effort and difficulty that sets expectations for teams attempting “true 3D” generation.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: first large world model product
quotes.text: the dots that lead you into the world was an intentional feature visualization, is not part of the model.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A counterintuitive product insight: user-delighting “explainability/preview” UI can be intentionally added outside the core model.

quotes.topic_title: Marble launch: first large world model product
quotes.text: it was really satisfying for us to hear that this intentional visualization feature that's not just the big hardcore model actually has delighted our users.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Practical lesson for builders: lightweight UX layers can drive user delight even when they’re not part of the “hardcore” model work.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases: VFX, games, robotics, therapy
quotes.text: Yeah, so we do believe that world modeling is very horizontal, but we're already seeing some really exciting use cases, virtual production for movies, because what they need are 3D worlds that they can align with the camera.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A practical framing for “world models” as a horizontal capability, anchored in a concrete near-term use case (virtual production) with clear requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases: VFX, games, robotics, therapy
quotes.text: So we were collaborating with those technical artists and directors, and they were saying, this has cut our production time by 40X.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A specific, memorable performance claim that quantifies impact and helps practitioners benchmark ROI for adopting 3D world-building tools in VFX pipelines.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases: VFX, games, robotics, therapy
quotes.text: One of the biggest pain point is to create synthetic data for training robots. And this synthetic data needs to be very diverse. They need to come from different environments with different objects to manipulate.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: Highlights a core bottleneck in robotics and gives an actionable requirement (diverse synthetic environments/objects) that guides tool and dataset strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases: VFX, games, robotics, therapy
quotes.text: Otherwise, humans have to build every single asset for robots. That's just going to take a lot longer.
quotes.speaker: Dr. Fei Fei Li
quotes.context: A blunt, counterweight to manual asset creation—useful for teams deciding whether to invest in simulation/world-generation to scale training data.

quotes.topic_title: Early Marble use cases: VFX, games, robotics, therapy
quotes.text: This is very much the way things work in AI. I've had other AI leaders on the podcast and it's always put things out there early as soon as you can to discover where the big use cases are.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A repeatable go-to-market methodology for AI products: ship early to learn real use cases and then focus investment accordingly.
